newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Kia Group crisis hits S.Korea's financial markets.
newsitem.headline: Kia Group crisis hits S.Korea's financial markets.

text.p: The crisis in South Korea's Kia Group has caused local stock prices to plunge, interest rates to rise and the U.S. dollar to appreciate against the Korean won, the Bank of Korea said on Thursday.
However, there hasn't been a noticeable change in conditions of local banks' overseas borrowings, the bank said in a statement reviewing the market impacts of Kia's trouble.

The central bank said Seoul's composite stock price index had fallen sharply to 727.63 points at 0400 GMT on Thursday, from 764.45 points on July 14, a day before Kia Group's creditor banks said they would protect Kia from default.
It said interest rates had risen on worries over tight liquidity conditions as a result of Kia.
Yields on the benchmark three-year corporate bonds rose to 12.10 percent on Wednesday, against 11.87 percent on July 14 and yields on commercial papers climbed to 12.74 percent from 11.84 percent.
The won closed at 893.70 on Wednesday, down from 891.40 on July 14.
The central bank said the dollar rose versus the won because of fears over possible difficulty in overseas borrowings following the Kia crisis.
It said short-term interest rates on some overseas borrowings had edged higher recently but mid- to long-term interest rates had remained stable.
